summary: the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a simple eukaryotic organism with approximately 6,000 genes. it is inexpensive to cultivate, can exist in either haploid or diploid states, and is extremely simple for genetic manipulations. more than 75% of the genes have an assigned function, while more than 40% share conserved sequences with at least one known or predicted human gene. ALS, called FUS, has been used to explore its biology in yeast. results suggest defects in RNA processing and transport may be a key element of ALS pathophysiology. in humans, the majority of FUS is found in the nucleus. yeast has the potential to be a much simpler and exciting system for modeling aspects of ALS. the results may open the way for more rapid progress in understanding the disease, its treatment, and the role of this new gene in ALS development. a growing list of viruses has been reported to undergo replication in yeast. these include RNA and DNA viruses that infect plants, insects, mammals, and humans. the study of the replication of RNA plant viruses was the first to be attempted using yeast cells. the yeast two-hybrid system, also called double-hybrid, has been
